Patient narratives:
90 year old man with acute right lower chest swelling sincefew months USG report tells no hepatic lesion, no subdiaphragmabscess, CXR shows no soft tissue or bony lesion - then can it beof cutaneous origin. blood report of acute infection. skinabscess? on palpation the swelling felt like a compressible gurglingmass reminiscent of hernia.  

See his CT scan here: USG abdomen report provided with the case tells normalimpression!! is there any infection in it? why neutrophil &ESR is high?.
Diagnosis: like abcess? inflammation?

Careful CT review

Surgical consult, monitor for incarceration/ischemia

Education, exercise, sleep optimisation, analgesia and antidepressant/neuromodulator as needed

Optimize thyroid, replenish iron

Correct deficits, reassure (hair regrowth)

Patient narratives: A 19 year old boy with fever for 2 weeks and recent evidenceof bilateral large pleural effusion with tachypnoea and withurine showing mild proteinuria with persistent active sediment:http://www.udhc.co.in/INPUT/displayIssueGraphically.jsp...Would appreciate your inputs on the diagnosis and plan forfurther management. This http://www.udhc.co.in/ViewImage?file_id=9819&scale=800was the reason for the patient's chest pain. The tap wasinitially showing 5000 WBC predominantly polymorphs alon withhigh pleural fluid to serum protein ratios and high pleural fluidLDH, s.
Diagnosis: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus?, Tuberculosis?

Define etiology (TB/parapneumonic/SLE)

Drain effusions, treat cause

Patient narratives: 50yr old male....presented with fever...tiredness....since 1week....examination febrile..no other findings....inv....denguens1 positive ...platelets were 60000....graduallyimproved.....was complaining of pain abdomen ...usgnormal...upper gi endoscopy showed gr D reflux esophagitis andchronic active duodenal ulcer.rut negative....patient continuesto have fever since 10 days started on antibiotic.....chest xraybronchitis....occasional crepts clinically...i just got a call heis desaturating ...abg....ph 7.51.po2 60..pco2 12..hco316....what am i dealing with? Shreniapologies for my delayed reply and yes the possibility ofALI is very strong given the clinical scenario. I must ask you todelete some of the images shared here as they reveal thepatient's name and this will be a threat to his privacy. Thebes.
Diagnosis: Dengue fever with evolving acute lung injury (ALI) / early ARDS and severe respiratory alkalosis
General Line of Treatment:
Immediate ICU transfer

Oxygen/ventilation, ARDS protocol

Patient narratives: A 14 years old boy having localized loss of hair and itchylesions in the scalp since few months sir this is case of cicatriacial alopecia please help us to take the history of this patient indetail. Sir , in this patient from the vertex on left side where wesee patches of alopecia with hyper pigmentation and atrophy usinga 4 mm punch we can take the biopsy. Clean the area and underproper asepsis after injecting 2 %lignocaine locally biopsycan.
Diagnosis: Localized scarring (cicatricial) alopecia, itchy scalp lesions, hyperpigmentation and atrophy on the vertex

Confirm fungus/biopsy

Anti‑fungal or anti‑inflammatory therapy (per final diagnosis)
column4: kerion is a boggy pus filled swelling over scalp

Patient narratives: give single ayurvedic diagnosis(may be more than 2) acc to the patient narratives which can be compared to modern diagnosis-with modern diagnosis and general line of treatment
Diagnosis: Rheumatoid arthritis (chronic inflammatory polyarthritis).
General Line of Treatment: Modern: DMARDs/biologics, low‑dose glucocorticoid as needed, physiotherapy and joint protection.

Patient narratives:
25 year old healthcare professional develops fever, nausea andvomitting. 2 days later he has yellowing of urine. LFT showsraised enzymes beyond 2000 IU, total bilirubin 3.8. 
INR 1.07.Repeat LFT after 2 days bilirubin 6.8, SGPT 3700.2 months back he has H/O intake of PEP with Zidovudine,Lamivudine, Lopinavir, Ritonavir for 1 month.IgM anti Hep A positive.
Diagnosis: Acute hepatitis A
General Line of Treatment:
The pattern is classic for acute viral hepatitis A: abrupt febrile prodrome with nausea/vomiting, followed a few days later by dark urine and jaundice; aminotransferases often rise 10–100× ULN (into the thousands), and bilirubin increases after the enzyme peak, with INR often normal unless fulminant failure develops.

IgM anti‑HAV positivity in this acute timeframe is highly specific for recent HAV infection and is sufficient for diagnosis in a compatible clinical setting; hepatitis A is self‑limited and does not become chronic.

Drug‑induced liver injury from zidovudine, lamivudine, lopinavir/ritonavir is a recognized but relatively uncommon complication and usually appears during or soon after exposure; here PEP stopped about 2 months before, while a clear acute HAV marker is present, making DILI a much less likely primary cause.

Patient narratives:
A 74 year old man with arthritis since 2 years and recurrentintermiitent angiodedema since 2 months angioedema is not common with rheumatoid arthritis but inthis patient there is associated history of hypertension anddiabetes both which can be the factors?? angioedema could be because of autoimmune factor inrheumatoid arthritis (perhaps only one case reported) and is morecommon with other autoimmune diseases. angioedema over jointswith pain may be associated with arthritis. Today I had time to look at the pictures for the firsttime. 
I do not see the angioedema. As the angioedema is occurringtwo years after the onset of the rheumatoid arthritis, I wonderif they are connected. As I commented earlier, I would be moreconcerned about a reaction to NSAIDs. 
First we must document thatthis patient does have angioedema , how was the diagnosismade??.
Diagnosis: Rheumatoid Arthritis

Patient narratives: A 40 year old man with irregular swelling of the right footsince 4 years Sir I have not seen this patient Sir this patient is not in my unit. Sir this patient is not in my unit.
Diagnosis: chronic Venous Insufficiency, mycetoma, elephantiasis
General Line of Treatment:
Examine, image (X‑ray/MRI)

Doppler, biopsy if mass

Patient narratives: We were unable to figure out why this 22 year old woman hadPolyarthritis for last 7 years,abdominal lymph-nodal tuberculosissince last 7 months, and pancreatitis 3 months with now recentlynoticed large liver cirrhosis and ascites.

Currently we are managing this 23 year old lady suffering fromsymptoms of malabsorption syndrome since the last 14 years whenshe was given a diagnosis of gluten sensitive enteropathy at theage of 9. No other neurological manifestations although not all ofthem may be present in all patients. The diagnosis of Coeliac wasmade 14 years back in Govt Medical College, Bhopal possibly as anassumption to see if she would respond to a gluten free diet(a Great to hear from Professor Dilawari(Santanu, Pralay, VivekJha, LakshmiKant Jha, Tarun Chakrabarti). 
We inquired and found that many laboratories in Indiahave discontinued the 72 hour Fecal fat test possibly due to theunpleasant logistic issues Please comment on:1 what were her symptoms when she was diagnosed CD.2. Was there D2 biopsy done.?.
Diagnosis: Chronic malabsorption with uncertain current etiology,coeliac disease.?

Patient narratives: A 40 year old woman with joint pains since 6 years
Diagnosis: Chronic inflammatory polyarthritis, most likely rheumatoid arthritis

Rheumatology referral

RA workup, DMARDs

Patient narratives: A 16 yr old obese girl has presented to us with acutepancreatitis and diabetes mellitus....... How do we progress toinvestigate the cause of pancreatitis in this girl? Its an interesting case.
Diagnosis: Acute pancreatitis, secondary diabetes

General Line of Treatment:
Optimize DMARDs/biologic

Taper steroids, monitoring

IV antibiotics, debridement

Patient narratives: A 40 year old man with gradual paralysis of both lower limbsand bedridden since 2 months

Patient narratives: A 60 year old woman with progressive abdominal wall tumorsince last 2 years
Diagnosis:
Desmoid tumor (aggressive fibromatosis) 
Need to rule out soft‑tissue sarcoma or metastasis with imaging and biopsy.

Imaging, core biopsy

Patient narratives: A 49 year old woman with vomiting and pain abdomen since 1month

Urgent imaging, labs

IV fluids, antiemetics, treat cause

Patient narratives: A 59 year old man with skin lesions and breathlessness since 2months.

Systemic vasculitis, pulmonary involvement 

Also consider paraneoplastic or infection‑related vasculitis or lung cancer with paraneoplastic skin changes

Patient narratives: 40 year old woman with difficulty in urination since 20
Diagnosis: Chronic female voiding dysfunction / bladder outlet obstruction or retention (long‑standing difficulty voiding)

Urogyne eval, PVR

Treat obstruction / pelvic floor

Patient narratives: 42 year old woman with pelvic pain and irregularmenstruation.
Diagnosis: Chronic pelvic pain with abnormal uterine bleeding – consider endometriosis, adenomyosis, uterine fibroid, or other causes of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB)

Pelvic US, AUB workup

NSAIDs, hormonal therapy

Patient narratives: 5 year old boy with inability to talk and walk since 4 yearsof age.
Diagnosis: Developmental regression / neuroregressive disorder with loss of walking and speech after prior normal development – consider childhood disintegrative disorder, Rett‑like or other neurodegenerative/metabolic cause

MRI, metabolic panel, rehab

Patient narratives: 26 year old woman with anemia since the last 2 years
Diagnosis: Chronic iron‑deficiency anemia, most likely due to menstrual blood loss or nutritional deficiency in a young woman

CBC, iron profile

Oral iron, treat source

Patient narratives: 32 year old woman with an intramural fibroid We are trying to get around the problem of difficult toread hand writing by asking our 'community health entrepreneur'to write with a printed hand:
Diagnosis: Intramural uterine fibroid (leiomyoma) in a reproductive‑age woman

If asymptomatic: observe

Patient narratives: A 78 year old woman with a cutaneous ulcer as well as aduodenal ulcer and renal failure This patient has again gotten admitted this time not withhematemesis but with persistent vomiting.
Diagnosis: Systemic vasculitis (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa or IgA vasculitis) with cutaneous ulcer, duodenal ulcer/bleeding and renal failure leading now to gastric outlet dysfunction and persistent vomiting

Urgent admit, stabilize

Endoscopy, vasculitis workup, immunosuppression

Patient narratives: A 17 year old man with recurrent jaundice and night sweatssince 2 months.
Diagnosis: Recurrent jaundice with constitutional B‑symptoms – must strongly suspect hematologic or hepatic malignancy (e.g., lymphoma with hepatic/biliary involvement) alongside other hepatobiliary or hemolytic causes

Urgent evaluation, labs

LFTs, imaging, hematology

Patient narratives:
A 45-year-old man having pain and burning sensation in wholebody and left frozen shoulder since six months we have planned for hot water fomentation in home and SWDND UST given along with that we have planned self stretching ndcaudmann,s pendular exercise can you support your management plan with some evidenceafter review of literature. Just google, frozen shoulder evidencebased management and let us know the salient points mentionedthere so that we can take this discussion forward. You need more history. 
All you have now is a shoulder thatwill not move. Did the patient have an injury in the past?? Couldhe have either a developmental abnormality or even past infectionin the shoulder? What about his paresthesias? What was hisneurologic exam like?
Diagnosis: Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder) with possible neuropathic features (burning, “whole‑body” pain requires further neurologic evaluation)

Patient narratives: A 32 year old man with post ejaculatory urinary burning since6 years
Diagnosis: Chronic prostatitis / chronic pelvic pain syndrome with post‑ejaculatory dysuria

Alpha‑blocker, analgesics

Patient narratives: during a survey conducted by our psm department i found a 35yrs old man with severe cough n dyspnoea for last one last year.cough is productive n stains d walls black or brown black. sleepis disturbed too.he works in a cement factory. case of pneumoconiosis???

Patient narratives: A young man with arthritis of left ankle followed byadditional pain and swelling developing over right knee followedby additional left wrist arthritis. We were initially not sure ofthe diagnosis until one of our medical students got a goodhistory from the patient:
Diagnosis: Migratory inflammatory arthritis – pattern highly suggestive of reactive arthritis or post‑infectious spondyloarthritis in a young man

NSAIDs, search trigger

Patient narratives: A 65 year old man with paralysis of right upper and lowerlimbs since 7 months
Diagnosis: Chronic right hemiplegia, most likely sequela of a prior left‑hemispheric ischemic stroke (persistent paralysis >6 months)

Stroke workup, prevention

Patient narratives: Our recent patient from Kolkata here in Bhopal, a past weightlifter in Kolkata police, relates developing a knee dislocationonce (subsequently proven to be a cruciate ligament tear...seerecent MRI done here) and yet within months of the knee injurywent on to win a local competition by lifting a heavy weight ofmore than 600 kilos. Currently here with recurrent cellulitissince the last few years
Diagnosis: Recurrent cellulitis of lower limb, likely on background of chronic edema/lymphedema or venous disease after prior knee trauma/surgery
General Line of Treatment:
Treat acute episodes

Manage edema, prophylactic penicillin

Patient narratives: A 10 year old child admitted with fever (intermittent) for 3months,joint pain in both knees and also back and wrist joint andthumb of left hand.Purpuric spots over abdomen,back of arm andback of thigh (both),no ecchymoses.History of moderate weightloss.Moderate pallor,swelling of both the knees and left wrist,nohemarthrosis,mild icterus.No significant bone pain.Noinvestigation reports done.What are the possible differentialdiagnoses upto this stage?
Diagnosis:
IgA vasculitis / Henoch–Schönlein purpura (palpable purpura on limbs/abdomen plus arthritis of knees/wrist; may have fever and weight loss)

Acute leukemia or other marrow disorder (fever, pallor, weight loss, purpura, joint swelling; bone pain can be mild or absent)

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis with associated vasculitic rash or thrombocytopenic purpura (chronic arthritis with purpura; needs platelets and inflammatory markers to distinguish)

Patient narratives: A 37 year old man having Right sided Abdominal pain since 4years and a lump since 2 years.
Diagnosis: Chronic right‑sided abdominal mass – consider abdominal wall or intra‑abdominal tumor such as mesenteric/abdominal wall lipoma, hernia, or renal/hepatic mass

Ultrasound/CT abdomen

Surgical opinion, excision

Patient narratives: A 36 year old man with severe knee arthritis and contractures(along with involvement of other joints including hands),progressive since 2 years
Diagnosis: Advanced rheumatoid arthritis with severe knee involvement and joint contractures (polyarticular, progressive over 2 years)
General Line of Treatment:
Aggressive DMARDs/biologics

Physiotherapy, consider arthroplasty

Patient narratives: A 60 year old woman with fatigue and reduced appetite for 1year
Diagnosis: Chronic fatigue with anorexia – must evaluate for malignancy, depression, endocrine disease (hypothyroidism, Addison’s), chronic infection, anemia
General Line of Treatment:
Full workup, screening

Treat underlying cause

Patient narratives: An 50 yr male patient having this skin problemsymptoms arewhite patches on both for arm n both of his for legshaving dryness with cracking without any oozing of fluidwith itching.
Diagnosis:
Chronic eczematous dermatitis (nummular eczema / lichen simplex–type dry, itchy, cracked white patches on extremities)

Less likely: vitiligo (usually non‑itchy, no cracking) or psoriasis (erythematous, well‑demarcated, silvery scale)
General Line of Treatment:
Emollients, topical steroids

Avoid irritants, antihistamines

Patient narratives: a 40 yr old man with complaints of fever, fatigue and memoryloss since 1 week
Diagnosis: encephalitis
General Line of Treatment:
Emergency admit, neuro eval

MRI, LP, IV antivirals

Patient narratives: 14 year old boy with Urinary incontinence, Knock knees, lowerlimb weakness and bone pains
Diagnosis:
Nutritional / metabolic rickets with genu valgum and bone pains (vitamin D or phosphate‑related)

Consider distal renal tubular acidosis or hypophosphatemic rickets as underlying cause

Vitamin D, calcium

Evaluate renal, phosphate

Patient narratives: 38 year old woman with complaints of severe neck pain and handpains radiating from the right shoulder since few months
Diagnosis: Cervical radiculopathy due to cervical spondylosis/disc herniation (neck pain with radiation to shoulder, arm, and hand)

NSAIDs, cervical collar

Patient narratives: A 40 year old man with abdominal distension.for 2 years.
Diagnosis: Chronic ascites with abdominal distension – most likely due to liver cirrhosis; consider malignant ascites or cardiac/renal causes

Ultrasound, diagnostic tap

Patient narratives: a 17 year old boy with fever and dry cough since 15 days.
Diagnosis: Atypical (walking) pneumonia – likely Mycoplasma pneumoniae (subacute fever with persistent dry cough in a teenager)

Chest X‑ray, labs

Oral macrolide, rest

Patient narratives: 30 yr old man with complaints of fever and bodyache since 4months and pain in right upper abdomen since 15 days
Diagnosis:
Hepatic (liver) abscess – subacute fever/myalgias with more recent right upper quadrant pain

Differentiate from acute cholecystitis, cholangitis, viral hepatitis

Ultrasound/CT abdomen

IV antibiotics, drainage

Patient narratives: A young male with history of chronic alcoholism. Presents tothe emergency dept. with History of Severe abdominal pain andrespiratory distress.
Diagnosis: Severe acute alcoholic pancreatitis with respiratory compromise (ALI/ARDS risk)

ICU care, aggressive fluids

Analgesia, NPO, treat ARDS

Patient narratives: Extreme Headache since 1 year
Diagnosis: Chronic daily headache – consider chronic migraine or chronic tension‑type headache after excluding secondary causes

Rule out red‑flags

Analgesic limit, prophylactics

Patient narratives: 35 year old woman with low grade fever for 4 months andassociated chronic diarrhoea

Other possibilities: chronic infectious diarrhea, celiac disease, microscopic colitis

Stool tests, colonoscopy

5‑ASA/steroids, hydration

Patient narratives: 66 year old woman with swelling in legs
Diagnosis: Peripheral edema – likely chronic venous insufficiency or systemic cause (heart failure, renal or liver disease, hypothyroidism, drugs)
General Line of Treatment:
Evaluate systemic causes

Leg elevation, compression

Patient narratives: 75 year old smoker presented with dry cough and low gradefever since 15 days.on examination he was afebrile.no clubbing nocyanosis resp. Rate 16/min.systemic examn nl trachea central,except reduced air entry on left side with hyperresonance
Diagnosis: Unilateral secondary spontaneous pneumothorax (smoker, reduced air entry with hyperresonance on one side)

Chest X‑ray confirmation

Oxygen, intercostal drainage

Patient narratives: 70 yrs old male came with complaints of Tingling sensation inboth lower limbs since 2 months, unable to walk for 1 month, andurinary incontinence for 1 month
Diagnosis:
Spinal cord compression / cauda equina syndrome (bilateral leg symptoms, inability to walk, urinary incontinence)
Decompression, steroids
General Line of Treatment:
Emergency MRI, neurosurgery

Decompression, steroids

Patient narratives: A 60yrs old female patient presented with the complaint ofdizziness and vomiting.
Diagnosis:
Acute vestibular syndrome – likely peripheral vertigo (BPPV or vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis) causing dizziness with vomiting

Must rule out posterior circulation stroke or cardiac cause in this age group
General Line of Treatment:
Urgent neuro/ENT evaluation

Vestibular suppressants, hydration

Patient narratives: 36 years old woman with polyarthritis for 20 years
Diagnosis: Chronic rheumatoid arthritis with long‑standing polyarticular involvement
General Line of Treatment: DMARDs, NSAIDs, physiotherapy

Patient narratives: A 57 yrs old female patient presented with dyspnea, cough withexpectoration, and mild fever
Diagnosis: Acute lower respiratory tract infection – acute bronchitis or community‑acquired pneumonia (dyspnea, productive cough, mild fever)
General Line of Treatment:
Vitals, chest X‑ray

Antibiotics, bronchodilators

Patient narratives: 27 year old woman with unexplained infertility for 2 years
Diagnosis: Primary female infertility – unexplained infertility after standard workup
General Line of Treatment:
Lifestyle optimization, counseling

OS‑IUI / IVF

Patient narratives: 70 year old man with shortness of breath and body swelling
Diagnosis:
Congestive heart failure with volume overload (dyspnea plus generalized edema in an elderly man)

Urgent evaluation, echocardiography

Patient narratives: This 45 year old woman came with cough and low grade fever of1 month duration , there is also history of significant weightloss. No hemoptysis or chest pain. No family history oftuberculosis.
Diagnosis:
Pulmonary tuberculosis – subacute cough, low‑grade fever, significant weight loss

Rule out lung malignancy or other chronic lung disease with constitutional symptoms
General Line of Treatment:
Chest X‑ray, sputum

Start ATT if confirmed

Patient narratives: This 25 year old woman came with pain and some swelling in herright wrist of four months duration. With no response to routineanti inflammatory meds. No other joints have any pain or swelling.
Diagnosis:
Chronic inflammatory monoarthritis of wrist – rule out early rheumatoid arthritis, seronegative inflammatory arthritis

Also consider tuberculous monoarthritis of wrist (chronic, NSAID‑unresponsive)
General Line of Treatment:
ESR, RF, imaging

Consider DMARDs / ATT

Patient narratives: A 7 year old girl with a wheeze every evening since the last 3months
Diagnosis: Childhood bronchial asthma / recurrent wheeze (symptoms daily, worse in evening/night)
General Line of Treatment:
Inhaled SABA trial

Controller ICS if needed

Patient narratives: a patient presents with shortness of breath, fever and araised ESR. On examination he had rash on his trunk and arms
Diagnosis:
Systemic inflammatory disease with lung and skin involvement – consider vasculitis or sarcoidosis

Also consider rheumatic fever or adult‑onset Still’s disease (fever, rash, high ESR)
General Line of Treatment:
Admit, evaluate urgently

Labs, imaging, biopsy

Patient narratives: A 7 years old child with intermittent left lumbar abdominalpain.
Diagnosis: Intermittent renal/ureteric colic – consider pediatric nephrolithiasis or UPJ obstruction
General Line of Treatment:
Urinalysis, renal ultrasound

Analgesia, hydration

Patient narratives: A 50 years old man with abdominal pain and loss of appetitesince 1 month
Diagnosis: Chronic abdominal pain with anorexia – red‑flag for intra‑abdominal pathology (peptic ulcer disease, pancreatobiliary disease, malignancy such as colorectal or gastric cancer)
General Line of Treatment:
Evaluate urgently, imaging

Basic labs, endoscopy

Patient narratives: A 50 year old woman with Diabetes since 10 years and recentknee pains and uncontrolled blood sugars
Diagnosis:
Type 2 diabetes mellitus – poorly controlled

Symptomatic knee osteoarthritis associated with diabetes
General Line of Treatment:
Optimize glycemic control

Analgesics, weight reduction

Patient narratives: A 31 year old woman with left knee pain and swelling since 6months and cough since 2 weeks
Diagnosis:
Chronic monoarthritis of knee – consider tuberculous arthritis of knee

Consider sarcoidosis with articular and pulmonary involvement
General Line of Treatment:
Joint imaging, synovial biopsy

ATT or steroids (cause‑specific)

Patient narratives: An 18 years old girl with polyarthritis since 1 year:
Diagnosis: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (chronic inflammatory polyarthritis) Differentiate from SLE, reactive arthritis, viral arthritis, early rheumatoid arthritis
General Line of Treatment:
NSAIDs, DMARDs initiation

Physiotherapy, joint protection

Patient narratives: A 50 years old woman with severe right sided headache since 5days
Diagnosis: Migraine, Tension type headache?

Patient narratives: A 70 year man with diabetes since 2 years and large boweldiarrhea since 4 months His diabetes appeared relatively well controlled but hislarge bowel diarrhea has been relentless
Diagnosis: hronic large bowel diarrhea Rule out: microscopic colitis, colorectal carcinoma, inflammatory bowel disease, diabetic autonomic neuropathy–related diarrhea
General Line of Treatment:
Evaluate, colonoscopy, biopsy

Fluids, electrolytes correction

Stop offending drugs

Anti-diarrheals cautiously

Patient narratives: 60 year old woman with Diabetes since 2009 and recentcellulitis As far as I can see from the records her DM duration is abt7 years..... Her sugars are pretty much uncontrolled with HbA1cabove 13..
Diagnosis: Type 2 Diabetes mellitus, Cellulitis
General Line of Treatment: Antibiotics, Glycemic Control

Patient narratives: A 45 years old woman with abdominal pain, fever and jaundicesince 2 weeks: you have seen this patient.
Diagnosis: Cholangitis
General Line of Treatment: Antibiotics, Biliary Drainage

Patient narratives: 44 yr man presented with fever, diarrhoea, dizziness &sweating. Initially BP was 100/60 with moderate dehydration. CRP50 with normal counts, Hb, Creatinine, Na/K & ECG.
Diagnosis: Acute Gastroenteritis
General Line of Treatment: Rehydration, Symptomatic

Patient narratives: A 45 years old man with chest pain since 5 months anddifficulty in breathing since 1 month
Diagnosis: Chronic Ischemic Heart Disease, COPD
General Line of Treatment: Revascularization, Pharmacotherapy
